quoteFirst: “They seem to be partial to moving in a restricted range, for I found that when following their tracks they always worked round in a circle. They are also very partial to disused zarebas, which they visit for the sake of the grass found there, and the finest animal I ever saw was observed sunning itself in the middle of such a zareba
quoteLast: . Naturally I had not my rifle, and my shikari, who had it, did not see the Koodoo, and though I followed it for some six hours I never got a chance at it; but it was a real beauty.
title: The book of antelopes, vol. 4 (of 4)
author: Sclater, Philip Lutley, 1829-1913; Thomas, Oldfield, 1858-1929

quoteTime: about nine o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: , I was at this post with five Frenchmen.  I had sent the rest of my people, consisting of fourteen persons, to look for provisions, of which I had been in need for several days.
title: Pathfinders of the Great Plains: A Chronicle of La Vérendrye and his Sons
author: Burpee, Lawrence J. (Lawrence Johnstone), 1873-1946

quoteTime: About nine o’clock in the morning
quoteLast: , on the 28th December, we left Macon and rode thirty-one miles distance to the Indian agency, on the left bank of Flint river, called by the Indians, Thlo-no-teas-kah. The road was partly sandy, partly rocky, but extremely uneven.
title: Travels Through North America, During the Years 1825 and 1826. v. 1-2
author: Bernhard, Duke of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach, 1792-1862

quoteFirst: Corps review was ordered for to-day, but it is raining, so very likely it will be postponed; started for picket
quoteLast: with Col. W. W. Henry as Officer of the Day, so we will fare well; rained all forenoon; cleared about 1 p. m.; fair since.
title: Personal Recollections and Civil War Diary, 1864
author: Abbott, Lemuel Abijah, 1842-1911

quoteFirst: [126] Its first appearance is not prepossessing, as it has no high steeples. The mass of houses, however, unfolds itself as you approach; the environs are low and monotonous. We landed
quoteTime: about nine o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: , in a cold high wind. The people whom we first saw were mostly negroes, or labourers.
title: Maximilian, Prince of Wied's, Travels in the Interior of North America, 1832-1834, part 1
author: Wied, Maximilian, Prinz von, 1782-1867; Thwaites, Reuben Gold, 1853-1913 [Editor]; Bodmer, Karl, 1809-1893 [Illustrator]; Lloyd, Hannibal Evans, 1771-1847 [Translator]

quoteLast: the King was dressed by the great Chamberlain, attended by all the Officers of the Bed-chamber. His Coat was Scarlet embroider’d with Gold, and brilliant Diamonds were his Buttons.
title:
The Memoirs of Charles-Lewis, Baron de Pollnitz, Volume III
Being the Observations He Made in His Late Travels from Prussia thro' Germany, Italy, France, Flanders, Holland, England, &C. in Letters to His Friend. Discovering Not Only the Present State of the Chief Cities and Towns; but the Characters of the Principal Persons at the Several Courts.
author: Pöllnitz, Karl Ludwig, Freiherr von, 1692-1775

quoteFirst: The demonstration proceeded, and it was carried out with keenness and with a very fair approach to accuracy. "Here is Malplaquet, which one passes
quoteLast: , and there by the candlestick is Red Fields, certainly on the main road and certainly paused at by"--he glanced aside at the other's face--"by the murderer, M. de Pincornet! Now let us mark this fox that doubles on himself.
title: Lewis Rand
author: Johnston, Mary, 1870-1936; Yohn, F. C. (Frederick Coffay), 1875-1933 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Hypochæris glabra Sp. pl. 811. These expand
quoteLast: , and close about twelve or one o’clock.
title:
Philosophical transactions, Vol. L. Part II. For the year 1758.
Giving some account of the present undertakings, studies, and labours, of the ingenious, in many considerable parts of the world.
author: Various; Royal Society (Great Britain)

quoteFirst: Thus we travelled on without interruption until we reached Danton, called Dantoon. This was
quoteTime: about nine o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: . At this place there is a dâk-bungalow--that is, a bungalow, or thatched house, built by Government for the accommodation of travellers. In Turkey it would be called a caravanserai.
title: A Popular Account of the Manners and Customs of India
author: Acland, Charles, 1812-1845

quoteFirst: I wirelessed, therefore, to d'Amade telling him he would not be able to land his men at "V" under Sedd-el-Bahr as arranged but that he should bring all the rest of the French troops up from Tenedos and disembark them at "W" by Cape Helles. About this time, also, i.e., somewhere
quoteLast: , we picked up a wireless from the O.C. "Y" Beach which caused us some uneasiness. "We are holding the ridge," it said, "till the wounded are embarked.
title: Gallipoli Diary,  Volume 1
author: Hamilton, Ian, 1853-1947

quoteLast: we started. It was about half-an-hour's work.
title: World's War Events, Vol. I
author: Reynolds, Francis J. (Francis Joseph), 1867-1937 [Editor]; Churchill, Allen L. (Allen Leon), 1873- [Editor]

quoteTime: About nine o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: the ship's company, having a minister on board with them, were at their exercises of devotion, which they have every morning, beginning with singing a psalm, as we do; then the minister prays, but not long, and the conclusion is to sing about two verses of another psalm, and so they part; except on the Lord's Day, as this was, their chaplain preached a short sermon in the morning in Swedish, but none in the afternoon.
title: A Journal of the Swedish Embassy in the Years 1653 and 1654, Vol II.
author: Whitelocke, Bulstrode, 1605-1675; Morton, Charles, 1716-1799 [Editor]; Reeve, Henry, 1813-1895 [Editor]

quoteFirst: We met a numerous caravan from Jenné, laden with salt. This caravan was composed of about two hundred men, sixty women, and twenty-five asses.
quoteTime: About nine o’clock in the morning
quoteLast: we halted at Sanasso. From Toumaré to Jenné wood is so scarce, that the greater part of the inhabitants burn millet-stubble.
title: Travels through Central Africa to Timbuctoo and across the Great Desert to Morocco performed in the year 1824-1828, in Two Volumes, Vol. I
author: Caillié, René, 1799-1838

quoteTime: About nine o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: , Otoo, the king of the whole island, attended by a great number of canoes full of people, came from Oparre, his place of residence and having landed on Matavai Point, sent a message on board, expressing his desire to see me there. Accordingly I landed, accompanied by Omai, and some of the officers.
title: A General History and Collection of Voyages and Travels, Volume 16
author: Kerr, Robert, 1755-1813

quoteLast: of the morning of the 27th, and received every attention and civility from him. The valley in which we had slept opened upon an extensive plain, to the eastward of which the Morumbidgee formed the extreme boundary; and it was in a bight, and on ground rather elevated above the plain, that he had fixed his residence.
title: Two Expeditions into the Interior of Southern Australia — Complete
author: Sturt, Charles, 1795-1869

quoteFirst: They rise at daybreak and work until their task is finished, often until far into the night. Two meals a day are provided for them, one at
quoteLast: and another between four and five in the afternoon. These consist of rice, fish and pork, and certain vegetables, and are abundant and palatable.
title:
China in America
A study in the social life of the Chinese in the eastern cities of the United States
author: Culin, Stewart, 1858-1929

quoteTime: about nine o’clock in the morning
quoteLast: , a little too late to get a breakfast at one of the stores, where sometimes the proprietor was sufficiently generous to accommodate a traveller with a meal for the moderate price of five dollars. The only resource was to lay a cloth on the storekeeper’s counter, and make a breakfast on crackers, cheese, and sardines.
title: Six months in the gold mines
author: Buffum, E. Gould (Edward Gould), 1820-1867

quoteLast: , with Tanacharison, the Half-King, Jeskakake, White Thunder and the Hunter, and arrived at Venango on December 4.
title: Daily stories of Pennsylvania
author: Godcharles, Frederic Antes, 1872-1944

quoteLast: , when in latitude 23° 45′ south, and longitude 2° 50′ east, on the 16th of February, having fine weather and calms, and light airs from south-west, a large piece of the _Laminaria buccinalis_, or trumpet-weed of the Cape, measuring, probably, twelve or fourteen feet in length, floated by the ship.
title: Wanderings in New South Wales, Batavia, Pedir Coast, Singapore, and China, Vol. 2 (of 2)
author: Bennett, George, 1804-1893

quoteTime: About nine o’clock in the morning
quoteLast: we left the village, after taking leave of the good old chief, who wished us a prosperous journey.
title: Travels through Central Africa to Timbuctoo and across the Great Desert to Morocco performed in the year 1824-1828, in Two Volumes, Vol. I
author: Caillié, René, 1799-1838
